commentBody: ETSY is back for a second straight day, making 11 appearances in 2025.  Let the conspiracy theorists have at it.
Easy, breezy, cover girl
When was the last time there was a 15x14 puzzle? (I must have missed it.)
The puzzle was fine.  The theme seemed like a bit of a stretch.  Nothing really jumped out at me about this one.
Loved this one. Great clues. Wonderful long entries. A nice puzzle before bed. And a good time for me - way better than my average. Thanks!

PB 5:04

Great little puzzle!

Since I played a lost child in Peter Pan in high school and we actually brought in the equipment to fly…. Aah the memories (no, I didn’t get to fly), FLY was my first thought. But that’s not a transportation. So BRR and POSE gave me the info for BUS. I can never spell NEEP Correctly though I knew it was the answer, so my misspelling hung me up a bit. However, still 4 minutes under my average Wednesday time. I can fly, I can fly, I can…

Not too difficult.

None of the clues were THAT DEEP. (See what I did there? I'll see myself out again.)
I don't know about you, but I've had some pretty deep power naps. It's always a gamble though; will I wake refreshed and bright, or feel like I've been drugged, wondering where I am.

I was flying through this thinking I was going to get a pb, then I got distracted by a scene in the movie Nonnas (Netflix) and left my phone on. Oops. Still finished 25% faster than my average Wednesday. 

I recommend the movie. Fun, lighthearted.
I’m not mad about it but I found this puzzle to be much easier than Monday or Tuesday this week.

"How'd you pay for that new pool?"
"Splash on delivery!"

(There are more swimming puns - you just wade and sea!)

Wondering if anyone not from the Northeast knows that Peter Pan is a BUS company or if nonfootball (US and overseas) fans know about the (Same Old) JETS?

Anyways, let's hear it for the EROICA, my favorite Beethoven Symphony  and a fun Wednesday puzzle.

I really wanted the column pic to be the “hang in there” poster 😊. Probably couldn’t do it for copyright reasons. So here it is (if the emus allow a post with a link to a commercial site): This is the version I remember from the 80s/90s https://www.amazon.com/Trends-International-Kitten-Hang-Bundle-Poster/dp/B07MNBQV7X Enjoy 😊

Hah! The BUS really made me wonder if I had perhaps fallen asleep and missed something when I watched Peter Pan as a child! Thanks for the explainer, Sam!

And whenever I see whiskey and RYE together I always think of the lyrics to American Pie. I thought that Don McLean had cleared up the meaning (that it was “drinking whiskey _in_ Rye” (the town) vs “whiskey _and_ rye”) in a documentary a few years ago. Or am I remembering this incorrectly? Hope someone here can set this straight!
I enjoyed it. Not that challenging, but fun cluing 😊.  It took me a long time to let go of ShovElPASS at 17 down though. ☺️
Sam, your dream of constructing a puzzle will come true but until the, I read your notes, hints after solving the puzzle because I so enjoy them.

As a regular traveler on NJ and Mass Turnpikes, the answer to 24D Peter Pan transport made me chuckle.

Hard clue for those living overseas or even outside Northeast US.
Regarding the Friends tab, there are scores for the Mini, Wordle, Connections, and Spelling Bee. Nothing for the Crossword? Am I missing something?

Re, the new "preview" look at the comments section. Thumbs totally down. 

1.  I replied to my own message, to comment that there is no "edit" button after one hits submit. Then Sotto Voce replied to my comment. What do I see below my OP? "1 reply." When you click on that, you see that it, too, has received "1 reply" and only when you click on that do you see Sotto Voce's comment. 

How is that, in any universe, an improvement?

Bring back the classic Coke style, where it simply says "2 replies." Jeez. The black preview banner at the top says "Replies are easier to follow now." Huh. What is it, opposite day?

2.   If you are scrolling down through "All" comments as opposed to "Reader Picks"  and get a little bored, and decide to click on "Reader Picks," you used to be returned to the top of the comments, where you'll usually find Mike from Munster hangin'. Not any more. When you click "Reader Picks" it does...something?

3.  I've already beefed about no edit button.

How very clever  to eliminate one row in the grid. It quite literally provides a visualization of IT’S NOT THAT DEEP. 

I like the inclusion of SOFA BEDS, which typically aren’t  deep either. 

Kudos to the constructor.
What's this about a Comment Preview?  Haven't seen anything about it.
Never heard of the Peter Pan Bus  Company.  I looked it up and saw it was in the Northeast only.  I used to ride the Badger Bus quite a bit.  Guess where that is located.

I'm not a great puzzler, but I enjoy the challenge (well, usually!)

I'm thrilled when I get through a non-Monday with only one look up -- now it could be there are a hundred comments about how easy this was, but I enjoyed it very much.

I tried to be trendy with DaP and went with IsLETS when clearly I needed to IRON out my thinking!   

Enough YAPing from me -- happy almost hump day!

Mr. Huynh writes: "I wanted to have four theme entries to capture the different meanings of DEEP: extending far down, extending far inward, thrown a far distance, profound. And the revealer provides a fifth meaning: difficult to comprehend." These are the kinds of things that leave me in awe of constructors' minds. They are, in fact, THAT DEEP. Tip of the hat to you, Mr. Huynh! I enjoyed the solve and the misdirects. Thank you! My only holdup was a silly one - ape before bat before CAT for "animal on a 'hang in there' inspirational poster." I could totally "see" an ape hanging off a branch or a bat hanging from the ceiling. I guess I'm not up to speed on inspirational posters... And now please excuse me while Chubby Checker teaches me to do the TWIST... https://youtu.be/-CCgDvUM4TM?si=Xm_ONu3NCFu_QhkJ

Thoroughly enjoyed this theme. Smooth solve, decent for a Wednesday, and a pretty grid. Peter Pan went completely over my head (pun intended). Had aortae before aortas so confidently entered VEEP since VPS was the last answer when  “number 2” was in the puzzle (I remember because I fleetingly thought it was something more scatological). Finally I’m not going to rip on the constant use of ISSA Rae and  ESAI Morales and ETSY—I build puzzles too, sometimes you do what you gotta do—but I still wonder how constructors ever survived before those actors and that website were popular?
My Diary a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/05/wednesday-august-6-2025/#ny

He says bocci, she says octopods, I say AORTAE (from the plural of αορτή which is αορταί) which would make for AEST which the acronym for the time this time of the year (winter) in Sydney. 

Absolutely in the “you had one job to do: add an edit after posting function” camp. 

Very nice puzzle. Many thanks.
With its ease, this felt like a Monday to me and Monday's felt like a Wednesday. Have we entered a wormhole?

Monday had too much baseball and Wednesday had too much (American) football.

Still, I enjoyed it. 

I had “ASL” for class with no written exams … which worked with “Brs” and “Duel” for paired number!

Started off with a gimme, and made steady progress through this one. Needed a few crosses from time to time, but no real sticking points. Had to make a couple of corrections, had LET lIE (that's an el, I dislike this sans serif font) and pAtS AT, but they were caught early.

Pleasant and enjoyable, Thanks Hanh!

I found this very easy despite being trivia-heavy, which usually greatly increases the difficulty for me (can you imagine how surprised I was when crosses revealed Peter Pan transport to be a... BUS??? The column explained to me what that was about after I finished my solve. Also, thankfully, the natickly crossing of J_TS and _SAI could only have been an E).

I wasn't rushing yet I solved quicker than yesterday. The grid wasn't very interesting or fun, either, for me. I didn't find the clues or the theme particularly enjoyable. Personally the whole thing felt like a so-so Tuesday puzzle.

Almost all sofas in our homes are SOFA BEDS. Most of us live in apartments, and not very big ones, either - a typical Polish flat is some 60 sq.m, with a living room, kitchen, bathroom, toilet, hall, and two bedrooms. For decades flat size was limited by design (the state built and gave them away before 1989, but without any luxury), and now by prohibitive prices (one sq.m. in Warsaw costs 2-3 monthly salaries). For families with children it's not uncommon for the parents to sleep on a sofa bed in the living room, with the bedrooms given over to kids. 

Even if that is not the case, almost nobody has a guest bedroom, so a sofa bed still makes sense for when you get overnight visitors.

I remember how surprised my mother and mother-in-law were when my wife and I got a non-bed sofa for our apartment - we went for form over function (but we have a large place, no kids, and a spare bedroom).
Great puzzle. Fast and fun.
Nice puzzle – and the choice of column photo, featuring legendary 1980s Radio 1 DJs, will hopefully tickle other Brits as it did me!
A football screen pass isn't typically quick. The quarterback usually waits to throw the ball, so the offensive LINEMEN have enough time to form a screen in front of the receiver.

Nice to see a pic of Steve Wright (L) along with his fellow Radio 1 DJs back in their prime. Wrighty was a comedy genius with the perfect radio presence who oversaw a zoo of characters on his daily show, the soundtrack to my teens and to my 40s (we were reacquainted, with the show moved to Radio 2). Irreplaceable. RIP.
IDK what's with this week, but the puzzles get easier and easier each day! This was even easier than yesterday, which was easier than Monday. I wonder if Thursday will continue this delightful cycle.
Nice and easy puzzle today. About 40 across, are the eggs green or is the go-with green? Neither sound very appetizing.
Lovely puzzle. But I thought I’d get something a bit chewier on a Wednesday
NEAP tide??? I’ve never ever heard of this, neap sounds like a made up word :(
Very nice theme, must have been fun thinking of very unrelated situations in which the word 'deep' can apply. Well done!
I believe that was my personal best for a Wednesday!
Nice Monday puzzle

Very straightforward for me today. No reveals, which is quite unusual. BUS and JETS would have been difficult but appeared with the crossers. If you live near a coast, then NEAP and Spring tides are familiar.

Fun puzzle, and I enjoyed both the clueing and the theme. I had to correct one answer.  For the “Fellow Down Under” clue, I confidently entered MAtt, congratulating myself for my cleverness in figuring that that out, but was wrong. Again.

Not all that easy for me, of course, but managed to work it out. And... really was not catching on to the theme at all while I was solving. Had to stop and ponder after I finished. That's just me. Puzzle find today - a Tuesday from April 3, 2018 by Damon Gulczynski. Don't recall another theme quite like this. The reveal clue and answer in that one: "To understand this puzzle's theme, read the ends of the answers to the starred clues and ... :" THINKQUICKLY And... the starred answers were clued straightforwardly. I'll just list the answers in order: NETFLIXQUEUE YESYOU MYEYE DEADSEA MARYKAY KALEL BUTWHY Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/3/2018&g=67&d=A I'm done. ....

Anyone else disappointed when the grid didn’t become three dimensional after solving it? Missed opportunity.


Other than that, it was perf (which is the first and last time I’ll use that “word”).
10 minutes under my Wednesday average and a Wednesday personal best.  Felt like a weak Tuesday to me.

Brilliant piece of work!
Got stuck on the last word in the puzzle's theme (11D.) and didn't take heed.
Sam C. to the rescue!
The penny didn't drop 'till I read her column.
And like Sam I too dream of constructing my own.
Maybe a 3x3 "micro" to start and then build from there?
I've never seen my niece's favorite movie but I've memorized the names of three characters: ANNA, ELSA, OLAF. They seem to appear in a lot of puzzles. It looks like a fun movie, maybe I'll watch it.

Hilarious that the photo at the top of the column is (L-R) Steve Wright, Bruno Brookes, Janice Long and Simon Bates obviously doing some promotional shoot for BBC Radio 1 back in the 80's! Who'd have thunk it?

Good crossword today.

Janice Long 
Simon Bates

What did I say yesterday about a certain word most often showing up on the edge of the bottom right-hand quadrant? I should preserve that wisdom, embroidered on needlepoint samplers, then sell them on-line. Here are Alex Baker & Stefan Woudenberg, performing a buoyant Chaconne by 17th-18th c. French composer Marin Marais--twelve strings, total: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eYYmqrzPFy0&list=RDeYYmqrzPFy0&start_radio=1 Had *no clue* what connected those four theme answers, until I filled out the revealer. Still, felt like a really small Sunday to me, or maybe an oversized mini.
Anyone else notice ETSY is an answer in almost every puzzle lately?
I had LETLIE for 51A, and looked right at ITSNOTTHATLEEP for a good couple of minutes before letting go of that L. Stubborn!
Ah, the BASTLE. Interesting choice by Disney to feature the classic stone-fortified farmhouse in their logo.

Did anyone else find [Stopped bringing up] / LET DIE kind of macabre and horrifying? I'm trying to think of an instance in which it's not awful.

Reminds me of the shortest tragic story: "For sale: baby shoes. Never worn".
Feels like NYT switched Tuesday and Wednesday this week.
Can you buy a ticket to Neverland from the Peter Pan BUS company? If I worked at Penn Station, I would definitely put that on the departures board, just for grins.

I'm reminded of the most adorable creature I met at a bodega years ago. She had been a cat model for inspirational posters. Oreo was her name. She said the hardest part of her work was hanging on to a bar for an hour-long photo shoot. She was one swole kitten! Meow! PAPER CUT....it might not be so wide as a church door, but it is ridiculously painful and inconvenient.  You get that many nerve endings in a small area and it's not so easily dismissed with an unsympathetic "IT'S NOT THAT DEEP."  (Hate people like that! Bah!)

Quilters will never give up their IRONs, which are absolute necessities!  And yes, I have two (one is a steam iron, and the other has a solid sole plate.  Parker Bros. made a mistake IMHO.

I have no idea what a SCREEN PASS is...and then there are LINEMEN and JETS.  I'd like to hear complaints about how many football-related clues there are from the folks that whine about baseball references.  (I like baseball.)
Kinda think the Peter Pan clue is a little too niche, otherwise really enjoyed this puzzle.  Thanks!
I think this is the third crossword in a row I've seen ETSY as a solution.
Pretty easy for a Wednesday, really enjoyed it though!

If I may opine: Several persons today have commented on NEAP: yes, it's Crosswordese; it's also basic scientific terminology--at least for those of us who, in the 1970's, poured over Rachel Carson's *The Sea Around Us (Adapted for Younger Readers)*. It's also vital terminology for those who live in seaside communities and make their livelihood from fishing; which few of us do, nowadays. Similarly, yesterday evening my Partner and I took a walk our neighborhood park; above us, through the Great Canadian Smaze, the moon--waxing gibbous--was dully shining. "Should be full next week, when we're Up North," said I, "No, this weekend--probably Sunday." My Partner--who is brilliant with finances and figures, and no dummy--replied "How can you tell?" As our civilization becomes increasingly technological, indoor, artificially lit, our perception and understanding of natural phenomena disappears. Nevertheless, even whilst our planet burns, they go on. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IYrZjwP2QuE (really, starts at 1:05)
For those wondering about a NEAP tide, you could always LOOK UP that word in the dictionary.  ;^)

Though it seemed a little easy for a Wednesday (as someone else mentioned, almost as if Tuesday & Wednesday flipped this week), this puzzle (and theme) was a lot of fun!

As other folks mentioned, Peter Pan had me a bit stumped. I never knew it was a bus line, but I'm glad to add it to my trivia stash!

I grew up in the northeast, yet I’d never heard of the Peter Pan bus  line until a few years ago when I went to Martha’s Vineyard. Peter Pan operates a shuttle that takes you from Boston Logan airport to Wood’s Hole, MA, where you catch the ferry to the island. So I knew that clue instantly. Good times!

Interestingly, the Peter Pan logo contains a little green-jacketed fellow who looks very much like the Disney character. I guess they altered it just enough to avoid copyright infringement?

Very nice puzzle, with a clever theme. Some tricky clues (like "Lose one's shirt", which had me stumped till the end). As for Peter Pan, I thought, "well, maybe the animated cartoon had a flying bus?" The constructor hit the right level of difficulty to be fun and challenging without being frustrating. 

Bravo! More from Hanh Huynh, please!

Obviously 24D had to be BUS but I still worried about Peter Pan taking a bus until I read the Column. I foolishly missed some other "had to be"s. How could I have imagined that they would toSS a football? That made 42A and 45A really hard, since I additionally imagined that there might be all kinds of protozoic E__s. Anyway, I fooled the app into thinking I upped my "streak" to 11 days.

Never thought I'd say this, but today was almost too easy for a Thursday. Solved in less than 9 minutes which, okay, it's nice to have a personal best, but I rather enjoy having to work at it a bit more. Fun solve, anyway!
Superb.

TIL I had the definition of NEAP tide exactly wrong, and that a spring tide doesn't mean it happens in March, April, or May. I love it when the crossword teaches me stuff.
When you've had too much whiskey in Rye, there's generally a bathroom on the right.

Surprised that no one has provided a link to the Peter Pan Bus Company: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Pan_Bus_Lines It was founded in 1933, well ahead of the Disney version, and named after the favorite picture book of the founder’s son. It provided an important transportation link for smaller towns in New England for a long time. I remember it coming to New London, NH when I was living there in the mid-70s. More recently, they entered into an agreement with MegaBus.

Hot diggity dog, it's my second Wednesday in a row solving with absolutely no extra clues. 

And now I fully expect to see a bunch of comments about how it was the easiest Wednesday ever and how they did it in an unsatisfying 53 seconds.
Aint it strange that not only do they use ETSY frequently, it's always in the SE corner....🤔

Didn’t care for this one. The “revealer” didn’t do anything to assist with the other highlighted vertical clues, so what was the point? Many answers just felt like, once again, the constructor sifted through the dictionary or Google, found some random esoteric words, and made that the core of their construction. I can’t respect it when constructors only wish to use these puzzles to flex their supposed knowledge (and the commenters who do the same).

Oh... one more late puzzle find - an unusual one. A Sunday from March 20, 2011 by Brendan Emmett Quigley with the title: "Chick Lit." The first theme clue was: "Chick lit book #1 (1992)" And every other theme clue was.... "Chick lit book #2 (#3) etc.) with the year the book was released in parentheses. those answers: THEPELICANBRIEF UGLYDUCKLING THESTERILECUCKOO SIXDAYSOFTHECONDOR TOKILLAMOCKINGBIRD THEMALTESEFALCON LONESOMEDOVE WHEREEAGLESDARE Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/20/2011&g=95&d=A ...

And... one more puzzle find. I'll re-post this one tomorrow. Thought it was quite clever. The theme answers, all clued straightforwardly except each was followed in parentheses by... (hint: 59 across) Theme clues and answers: "Classic learning-to-read series (hint: 59-Across)" JANEANDDICK "Virginia university (hint: 59-Across)" MARYANDWILLIAM "Grimm fairy tale (hint: 59-Across)" GRETELANDHANSEL "Shakespeare play (hint: 59-Across)" JULIETANDROMEO And.. 59 across: "Chivalrous rule obeyed in this puzzle" LADIESFIRST Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/20/2015&g=23&d=A .....
Frozen and Dr Seuss? My toddler would be thrilled.
Super fun! Thank you. :-)

I almost never nap anymore. But I remember napping on Saturday afternoons when I was in my 20s. I'd wake up around 7 PM, look at the clock, look at the twilight, and wonder if it was Saturday evening or Sunday morning.

@Eric Hougland

I don't usually nap, but just last year I had a nap like the one you describe and it completely freaked me out not knowing if it was night or morning. I felt completely lost in time and space, and it was a terrible feeling.

@Eric Hougland

That was my dilemma when I worked nights. I woke up one time to gray skies, with 6:00 showing on my analog clock, and had no idea whether it was morning or night. Of course this was long before cell phones, so I finally turned on the TV to see what programs were on to figure out whether I could go back to bed or not.

@Jeb Jones The one I remember from the 1970s was in black & white and showed the cat more head-on. And the cat was using both its front paws to hang. Wikipedia concurs: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hang_in_there,_Baby

@Jeb Jones

@Eric Hougland
I think it was a very common…meme? I can’t think of another word to use, sorry! Those “inspirational posters” were every where at one time…schools, office break rooms, drs and dentist offices, coffee shops…ubiquitous. Not surprised that there are numerous takes on the image.

@Canoe-er that was an extremely regional clue. I filled it from the crosses and I didn’t understand it until coming here. But now that I get it, I think I have heard of the company and have definitely lived in the region where it operates (and may live in it now).

@Canoe-er

You peaked my interest because that's where I lived when I was a kid, in Rye. So I went down the rabbit hole and found this:

"(Don McLean)was born in New Rochelle, NY. While some speculate that "whiskey in Rye" in "American Pie" refers to Rye, NY, McLean himself has stated that the lyrics are about "whiskey and rye" in general, and that the song is not specifically about Rye, NY, according to Westchester Magazine. He also clarified that he wasn't frequenting bars in Rye during the time the song is set, according to Westchester Magazine."

The thing is, New Rochelle is only 8 miles from Rye, so I guess that's why many thought he might be hanging out in Rye, "drinking whiskey in Rye."

I also found out that The Levee was a bar in New Rochelle that he indeed did frequent. 
("Drove my Chevy to the levee but the levee was dry.")

What's funny to me is that, in the past week, I've heard the song twice on the radio while driving. I listened intently to the lyrics and concluded that Don McLean was high as a kite when he wrote this fabulous song. :-)

@Canoe-er

I don't know, but there's no song that makes me more think of my dad than that one. It brings back an image of him and his overalls working on some old Studebaker or some such in our garage. That song seemed to always be on the radio. It was probably only one time, but in my memory it was every time.

@Canoe-er The clue generated an image of Tinker Bell and her pals looking out the windows of a bus flying through the nighttime sky before being rejected. When the crosses forced me to enter BUS I began to think I might be losing it. @Andrzej

Our homeroom teachers are not that involved with us.
Homeroom is just the room we are assigned to report to at the beginning of the school day. (This is for middle school and high school, where students are taught different subjects by different teachers through the day.) 
The homeroom teacher takes attendance, and we listen to the morning announcements, and pledge allegiance to the flag. That's the only time we see the homeroom teacher, and they go on to their regular teaching assignments for the rest of the day.

@Andrzej

Yes, the Pledge of Allegiance in school is weird.
I think it was meant to push the idea of being loyal to the US as a democratic ideal of a nation as opposed to being loyal to a specific person or royal family or authority.

Seems a bit hollow these days. YMMV.

@Linda Jo
Do young people ever refuse to join in with the Pledge?
When I was in my teens, the national anthem was played in cinemas and theatres at the end of the evening. Aged about 16 some of us would stay sitting - we were anti-royal (still am).

Then people starting dashing to the doors as soon as the curtain started to come down, but if they didn't make it out, they would stop until the end of the anthem. Soon, people started leaving anyway, and by 1970's the playing of the anthem stopped.

But then, protest was in the air in those days.

@Bill

Our terminology related to the places we live is much simpler. A house (as in, a standalone building one might live in) is "dom." A unit in a building of many units is a "mieszkanie." Whether you rent or own it, the terminology does not change.

Most Poles aim to buy their own dom or mieszkanie. Usually people will take out a mortgage to manage the cost. A typical term for such a loan is 30 years, and the monthly repayments are a heavy burden on the household's budget for all that time (AFAIK a typical repayment for a typical Warsaw mieszkanie is about the same as a minimum monthly salary, which in turn is about half of a typical Warsaw salary).

Renting is only ever considered temporary, tbh.

"Dom" also means "home," as in the place you live, be it a mieszkanie, dom (in the narrow sense), an extended residency hotel, etc.

Aaaaand I ran out of room, as usual :D

Let me continue here:

When a seller lists a mieszkanie, they always provide the total price and the price per square meter. The latter makes it easier to compare prices of mieszkania (that's the plural or mieszkanie) of different sizes.

In rental offers, the cost per mieszkanie per month is provided, usually split between what you pay: 1. the owner of the mieszkanie, 2. the owner/administrator of the building (usually a different entity than the owner of the mieszkanie), 3. the utility companies.

(BTW, when talking about fuel efficiency, we use different measures than Americans, too. We speak of how many liters a car uses per 100 km. For example, our VW Golf needs ca. 6l of gasoline per 100 km travelled, while our Mustang requires three times that. Eeeek!)

@Bill

So _that’s_ what a condo is! I’ve never been sure. I think I hear about them most commonly in the context of people retiring in one in Florida, so assumed there was some sort of retirement/aged community aspect to it. Never occurred to me that it was just owned vs rented. 

Here we just have houses and units (and I suppose townhouses). 
A house is freestanding. A unit is a residence in a building with other residences (we might also call that an apartment). A townhouse is somewhere in between — a mostly freestanding house that perhaps shares a wall or two with the neighbouring houses. 
Whether you rent or own it is irrelevant.

@Alexis I always had a similar idea of condos, like they were controlled differently in some way than an apartment, never knew it was just ownership. 

In the UK we very simply have houses and flats (though luxury flats are sometimes marketed as 'apartments' for some reason). 
In a house you have every floor from the bottom to the top and your own entrance, utilities etc. These can be terraced (a row of houses all sharing side walls), semi-detached (two houses sharing a wall), or detached (free-standing). 
Flats could be an entire floor of a house with its own entrance or a unit in a bigger building. They can sometimes be two storeys, but will never be from the ground to the top of the building, and will generally share utility infrastructure. 

We do also have the concept of a townhouse, but that's usually just a house (most likely terraced) in a dense urban area, where you'd be more likely to find flats. And they're most likely to be old buildings (georgian/victorian probably) So, for example, if you owned a house in Soho in London, you might say you have a townhouse, as most houses there have been converted to flats. But there's no actual definition difference between a townhouse and a normal house, and it's usually just very fancy houses in London that get called townhouses.

David,

As a fellow Londoner noted in another thread an hour after your post, "If you live near a coast, then NEAP and Spring tides are familiar."
In a sense, as high water relative to low, NEAP tides are not that deep (compared to spring tides).

@RozzieGrandma - slight correction: when the moon is directly between or directly opposite the sun, a spring tide is the result (as you said, new or full; but a new moon is not opposite the sun but hidden by it).

@David Connell

I think, though, that having the sun and moon on the same side (new moon) also creates a Spring tide.

The difficult thing about tides is we imagine the oceans being pulled towards the moon (or more weakly, to the sun).

In fact, the moon creates a bulge of water on *both* sides of the planet, not just on the side nearer the moon.  So the moon, by itself  creates two high tides and two low tides a month.

The sun does the same, but only about half as strong.  Yet when the sun and the moon creates a bulge in the same direction, we get additive effects, making for  larger tide than normal.

Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong.
@Jane Wheelaghan I think it is good construction when the more obscure facts have easier crossers.

@Bill

Around the time you were taking your walk in the park I was watching the tennis matches from Canada. They showed a picture of the moon, which was in the crescent phase. 

I must have been hallucinating, but I went back and looked again and I will swear it was a crescent moon they were showing.

I thought maybe there was some very strange astronomical aberration affecting the moon in your region but here you are telling me you saw a waxing gibbous, which is what I was seeing out my window and I imagine anyone else in the entire world was seeing as well when they looked at the moon.

Go figure. One thing to add: it has been a really long time since I was in a place free of light pollution and got to see the night sky in all its splendor. I wonder how many young urban dwellers today have ever seen anything but a few stars and think that's all there is.

@Roberto
I mentioned going to our place "Up North"--not all that high a latitude, really, about 44.9°N. But far a way from any large city, and with relatively clean air. On a clear summer might, one can make out the Milky Way quite well; and in winter, Orion/Sirius/Taurus are quite stunning!
But now, more and more homes around the lake are keeping lights on all night; and of course there's the smoke from the arctic wildfires which are becoming an annual event*. So even there, the stars are fading.

*not that I'm blaming Canada, mind you.
